member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.CacheQueryOptions
member.summary: Options that allow queries that will be run against cache to share the same semantics as the corresponding query against the Entity Framework and the backend database. Linq To Objects (CLR) and Linq To Entities do not share the same semantics. This class allows IdeaBlade Entity queries against the Entity cache (Linq to Objects queries) to be interpreted like they will be against the Entity Framework.

member.summary: Determines case sensitivity of Cache queries.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.CacheQueryOptions.UseSql92CompliantStringComparison
member.summary: Determines whether String comparisons are performed according to the ANSI SQL92 specification. In particular, the ANSI standard requires padding for the character strings used in comparisons so that their lengths match before comparing them.
member.remarks: Note that this is typically NOT enforced for operations that rely on the SQL 'Like' operator such as 'StartsWith' 'EndsWith' and 'Contains'. So, for example: "ABC" == "ABC " -> true but "ABC".StartsWith("ABC ") -> false

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.CacheQueryOptions.GuidOrdering
member.summary: Determines whether to use standard CLR semantics for sorting Guids or the SQL Server default mechanism in which only the last 6 bytes of a value are evaluated.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ComplexObject
member.summary: Abstract (MustInherit in Visual Basic) base class for any complex type properties used in entities within DevForce.
member.remarks: ComplexObjects are effectively lightweight entities with no primary key (i.e. no independent identity) that are hosted as properties of an or nested within another ComplexObject. They are analogous to the used within the Microsoft Entity Framework. When you define a complex type within your conceptual model, the DevForce Object Mapper generates a sub-classed ComplexObject in the auto-generated domain model for it.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.CacheStateManager
member.summary: Used to store and retrieve the EntityManager's cache from a stream or file.
member.remarks: You can access the CacheStateManager used by an EntityManager through the property. Use to store the entity cache to an external source, and to restore a previously saved cache.

example.code:
Private Sub SampleEntityCacheUsage()
Dim mgr As New DomainModelEntityManager()
' Cache all employees. mgr.ExecuteQuery(Of Employee)()
' Save the cache to local storage. mgr.CacheStateManager.SaveCacheState("c:\temp\entitycache.bin")
' Ocassionally-connected users will normally connect, cache all data required, ' then disconnect and work from local cache and/or locally saved cache until they can reconnect. ' In this example, we'll mimic a disconnected login for this user by clearing all cached data ' and then re-loading the cache from local storage. mgr.Disconnect() mgr.Clear()
mgr.CacheStateManager.RestoreCacheState("c:\temp\entitycache.bin")
' Let's reconnect and get more data now. mgr.Connect() mgr.ExecuteQuery(Of Customer)() End Sub

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.CacheStateManager.SaveCacheState(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stores the state of this EntityManager and all cached entities to a stream.
member.param: Stream to be written to.
Whether or not to close the stream on exiting this method.
True to save the data in binary format; false to use text format.
member.remarks:
The current state of the EntityManager and all entities in its cache will be saved to the stream in either binary or text format.
You can use a with this method to create an encrypted output file.
In Silverlight and other applications running with reduced privileges, you can use an with this method.

member.param: List of entities
Stream to be written to.
Whether or not to close the stream on exiting this method.
True to save the data in binary format; false to use text format.
member.remarks:
The current state of the EntityManager and the specified entities will be saved to the stream in binary format.
You can use a with this method to create an encrypted output file.
In Silverlight and other applications running with reduced privileges, you can use an with this method.

member.summary: Default implementation of the interface.
member.remarks: This is a stub for Silverlight applications. Deploy your custom implementation of to the server.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IDataSourceKeyResolver
member.summary: Interface used to resolve the data source key which will be used to connect to a data source.
member.remarks:
The is used by default to determine the key and connection information to be used when accessing a data source. To override this behavior implement a custom IDataSourceKeyResolver. If a custom IDataSourceKeyResolver is found, a single instance of the class will be created for the and called for all data source key resolution.
If using a custom IDataSourceKeyResolver you will not need to place data source key information in your IdeaBlade Configuration file.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IDataSourceKeyResolver.GetKey(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the for a given key name and extension.
member.param: Data source key name
Extension or empty string
True if called from the EntityServer
member.returns: A data source key or null if default key resolution is desired
member.remarks:
If a null key is returned the will attempt to resolve the key.
GetKey will be called once per keyName and keyExtension on both the client and server. If you need to secure your client connection information you may want to implement separate versions of this class on the client and server tiers.
The returned is stored in a map, and the same key is reused whenever the same key name and extension are encountered. Note that on the server this means that the same key will be used by any users of your application: user-specific keys are not supported.
Any exception thrown in your GetKey implementation will be returned to the calling client.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.DefaultDataSourceKeyResolver.GetKey(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the for a given key name and extension.
member.param: Data source key name
Extension or empty string
True if called from the Entity Server
member.returns: Concrete data source key
member.remarks: Returns a for the given name and extensions.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect
member.summary: Provides entity services for all persistable business objects used within DevForce.
member.remarks:
The EntityAspect implements interfaces to support editing, change tracking and change notification. One instance of the EntityAspect class is associated with each persistable entity within a domain model. The also extends the EntityAspect
An EntityAspect can be used to an object and provide it with entity-related services.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.AddToManager
member.summary: Adds a newly created entity to its associated .
member.remarks: The associated EntityManager will either be the EntityManager that was called to create this Entity () or that was used to generate its ids ( ) If neither of these cases apply, then the 's DefaultManager"/> will be used. There is no difference between AddToManager and . Use either method to add a business object created by the method to the EntityManager cache. The object must have a "detached" , must not have ever been associated with another EntityManager and must have a unique EntityKey within the EntityManager to which it will be added.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.AddToManager(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager)
member.summary: Adds a newly created entity to the specified .
member.remarks: If the entity is associated with an EntityManager (i.e. the Entity Manager that was called to create this Entity () or that was used to generate its ids ( )), the EntityManager passed in the parameter must be the same. There is no difference between AddToManager and . Use either method to add a business object created by the method to the EntityManager cache. The object must have a "detached" , must not have ever been associated with another EntityManager and must have a unique EntityKey within the EntityManager to which it will be added.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.RemoveFromManager(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes the entity from the EntityManager cache.
member.remarks:
The Entity will be in a "detached" state after the remove. RemoveFromManager and can be used interchangeably. Calling RemoveFromManager also clears the EntityManager's .
This does not delete the object from the backend server. To delete an entity, use the method.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.AcceptChanges
member.summary: Accepts all changes to this Entity, returning the EntityState to Unchanged.
member.remarks:
AcceptChanges is automatically called by the EntityManager after a successful call; there is rarely a need to call this method directly.
The and events are fired with an EntityAction of when this method is executed.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.RejectChanges
member.summary: Rejects (rolls back) all changes to this Entity since it was queried or had called on it.
member.remarks:
Rejects any changes made to the Entity since the last save operation. This will also remove the Entity from the EntityManager if it was an 'added' object.
The and events will fire during a RejectChanges call with an EntityAction of .

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.ForcePropertyChanged(System.ComponentModel.PropertyChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: Forces a PropertyChanged event to be fired.
member.param: A or null
member.remarks:
An Empty value or a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) for the propertyName parameter of PropertyChangedEventArgs indicates that all of the properties have changed, causing the .NET framework to also fire a ListChangedEventArgs.ListChangedType of "Reset" if the event propagates to a list that supports the ListChanged event.
Passing a null value to this method will insure that a valid (dynamically created) property name is passed on to any listeners.
This method should only be needed in situations where changes to calculated fields or other properties not backed by an must be made known.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityAspect.CloneCore
member.summary: For internal use only. Makes a copy of the entity including its EntityState; it does not copy related entities.
member.remarks:
CloneCore copies the Entity "in depth" including the entitys . Related entities are not copied. Derived classes that override CloneCore typically call base.CloneCore first to let DevForce do the initial cloning before proceeding to their custom functionality.
Beware: the result of CloneCore is not attached to any EntityManager even though the value of its EntityState indicates that it is! CloneCore should be called only within a Clone() method that understands this and that will ultimately expose the cloned entity as a properly formed entity with a correct EntityState.
The source EntityState is preserved so that the calling Clone() method can know and make use of the source entitys EntityState. It is critical that the calling Clone() method return a properly formed Entity which means that, unless the method attaches the clone to a different EntityManager, the returned clones EntityState should be reset to "Detached".
CloneCore is called within other DevForce Clone() methods (EntityGroup.Clone for example). You can invoke it yourself by casting the entity as and calling Clone() as in (Foo) ((ICloneable) foo).Clone()). The resulting clone does not belong to an EntityManager and its EntityState is "Detached".

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManagerContext
member.summary: Allow the construction parameters of an EntityManager to be created independently of the EntityManager.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManagerContext.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityServiceOption,System.String,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManagerOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Allow the construction parameters of an EntityManager to be created independently of the EntityManager.
member.remarks:
You can use the to determine the run-time data source key(s) to be used. Every EntityManager (and EntityServer) is associated with a data source extension. By default, if an extension is not specified, then an "empty" extension is used. See the "Data Source Keys, DataSourceKeyResolvers, and Data Source Extensions" topic in the DevForce Resource Center for more information on data source extensions. The use of different data source extensions can be especially beneficial as you move your application between development, test and production environments, and for other situations in which the data source to be accessed will be determined at run time. The resolved DataSourceKey(s) must either be specified in the IdeaBlade configuration file or through a custom implementation of .
You can also choose whether a connection to the should be made now. If is true you will not be able to catch any thrown due to connection problems in an handler since the handler will not yet be set; you should instead wrap the call in a try/catch. If is false then you will need to call the method when you are ready to begin communicating with the EntityServer.
Use the to explicitly specify whether you will be using local or distributed data sources. By default the ObjectServer element in the IdeaBlade configuration file determines this, but if you need to use both local and distributed data sources within the same application you'll use the EntityServiceOption to indicate what the EntityManager will use. See the "Access Both Local and Remote Data Sources In the Same N-tier Application" topic in the DevForce Resource Center for more information.
You can also provide the name of the CompositionContext to be used to compose parts for runtime extensibility. By default if you don't provide a name the "default" context is used. See the CompositionContext for more information and sample usage.
Use the to specify the named serviceKey element indicating the address of the application server used by the EntityManager.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryPager`1
member.summary: A pager which allows results to be paged either synchronously or asynchronously.
member.remarks:
Use the EntityQueryPager to manage paging of query results. The query can return items of an entity or anonymous type. When creating the EntityQueryPager the baseQuery determines the selection criteria, and also indicates the in effect and the used.
The QueryStrategy of the baseQuery controls whether paging is managed over just the local cache (QueryStrategy.CacheOnly), just the database (QueryStrategy.DataSourceOnly), or both ( QueryStrategy.DataSourceThenCache). Merge semantics are determined by the baseQuery.QueryStrategy.MergeStrategy.
No query is executed until the first MoveTo method is called. You'll usually call or to get things started. You can then move forward and backward through query results using the and methods or their asynchronous counterparts. As paging is performed a query is executed for the specific "page" of the overall query results using the appropriate "skip" and "take" LINQ operators. allows you to go directly to the final page of results. The and are used to indicate the current page and its data. When using the asynchronous API, query results are also returned in the .
The and events are fired for all syncrhonous and asynchronous "MoveTo" calls.
An is required to provide for ordered, and orderly, paging. Ideally the sort selector should guarantee that no two records have the same sort position, however the pager will still work with 'nonunique' sorts but performance will be improved the more unique the sort.
If the baseQuery's EntityManager is cleared then this will trigger a call within this instance.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryPager`1.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IEntityQuery{`0},IdeaBlade.Core.ISortSelector,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a pager to manage query results.
member.param: The base query
Sort criteria
Page size
member.remarks: The provided must be "attached" to an , since it's the EntityManger which will execute the query and cache its results. The is required and can be a simple or composite expression. The must be greater than 0.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager
member.summary: Management class for all high-level retrieval, caching and persistence operations on entities.
member.remarks:
The EntityManager is responsible for communicating with an to retrieve entities from and persist entities to their backend data sources, managing entities in its cache, creating new entities, ensuring entity security, and persisting its cache to local storage to facilitate disconnected access.
A single EntityManager can manage entities backed by any number of data sources. It caches entities and queries, both to improve performance and to support offline operation of applications. Entities remain in the cache until the application terminates or they are explicitly removed.
Use Login and to validate a user's credentials and provide session-level security to the . You'll need to implement to perform this validation. If login security is required, be sure to call Login prior to performing any other EntityManager actions.
Use and to explicitly manage connection state to the EntityServer. Use the delegate to set up an error handler to catch connection and other EntityServer problems.
Use any of the ExecuteQuery overloads to explicitly retrieve entities from either a backend data source or the EntityManager's cache. When using an or any query implementing you can also take advantage of "deferred execution" and implicitly retrieve the requested results by enumerating over the query or calling either ToList() or ToArray(). For more information on deferred vs. immediate execution and LINQ queries, see the Language-Integrated Query topic in the Visual Studio documentation.
Use CreateEntity or its overloads to create new entity instances, and AddEntity to add the new entity to the entity cache. Use one of the SaveChanges overloads to persist changed entities to a backend data source.
Use CacheStateManager.SaveCacheState to save cached data and the state of the EntityManager to the local file system. Use CacheStateManager.RestoreCacheState to restore from the saved file. Use to move entities between EntityManagers.
Corresponding asynchronous methods are available for any operation which may access the EntityServer. See , , , and .
Note: The EntityManager is not thread-safe.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityServiceOption,System.String)
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityManager class for the specified data source key extension and optionally connect to the EntityServer, with the option to use local or distributed data sources.

Determines whether to use local or distributed data sources.
Optional name of the CompositionContext to use for MEF composition.
member.remarks:
You can use the to determine the run-time data source key(s) to be used. Every EntityManager (and EntityServer) is associated with a data source extension. By default, if an extension is not specified, then an "empty" extension is used. See the "Data Source Keys, DataSourceKeyResolvers, and Data Source Extensions" topic in the DevForce Resource Center for more information on data source extensions. The use of different data source extensions can be especially beneficial as you move your application between development, test and production environments, and for other situations in which the data source to be accessed will be determined at run time. The resolved DataSourceKey(s) must either be specified in the IdeaBlade configuration file or through a custom implementation of .
You can also choose whether a connection to the should be made now. If is true you will not be able to catch any thrown due to connection problems in an handler since the handler will not yet be set; you should instead wrap the call in a try/catch. If is false then you will need to call the method when you are ready to begin communicating with the EntityServer.
Use the to explicitly specify whether you will be using local or distributed data sources. By default the ObjectServer element in the IdeaBlade configuration file determines this, but if you need to use both local and distributed data sources within the same application you'll use the EntityServiceOption to indicate what the EntityManager will use. See the "Access Both Local and Remote Data Sources In the Same N-tier Application" topic in the DevForce Resource Center for more information.
You can also provide the name of the to be used to compose parts for runtime extensibility. By default if you don't provide a name the "default" context is used. See the for more information and sample usage.
No connection to data sources is made during EntityManager initialization.
An event is fired upon creation.
member.exception: Thrown in a Silverlight application when BOS is not specified

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,System.Boolean,System.String,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityServiceOption,System.String)
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityManager class using the credentials and settings from another EntityManager, but with the connection state, data source extension and options specified.
member.param: EntityManager to copy settings from
True if a connection to the EntityServer should be made.
The DataSourceKey extension to search for in IdeaBlade configuration file.
Determines whether to use local or distributed data sources.
Optional name of the CompositionContext to use for MEF composition.
member.remarks:
This copy constructor will create a new "empty" (no data) EntityManager with the same settings and defaults as the specified EntityManager. The connection state, data source extension, and option for distributed or local data sources specified here will override the values from the source EntityManager. The new EntityManager will be "logged in" to the EntityServer with the credentials already provided in the passed EntityManager.
An event is fired upon creation.
member.exception: Thrown in a Silverlight application when BOS is not specified

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManagerContext)
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityManager class using the credentials and settings from another EntityManager.
member.param: EntityManager to copy settings from
EntityManager constructor parameters
member.remarks:
This copy constructor will create a new "empty" (no data) EntityManager with the same settings, defaults and connection status as the specified EntityManager. The new EntityManager will be "logged in" to the EntityServer with the credentials already provided in the passed EntityManager.
The VerifierEngine associated with this new EntityManager is determined by whether this ctor is called on the same thread as the entityManager passed in. If so, then the two entityManagers will share a single VerifierEngine, if not, a new VerifierEngine will be created for this entityManager. This behavior is intended to avoid threading issues because VeriferEngines ( like EntityManagers) are not thread safe.
Other than the login credentials and connection state, the settings copied from the source EntityManager are , , , and .
An event is fired upon creation.
member.exception: Thrown in a Silverlight application when BOS is not specified

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.ConnectImplicit
member.summary: Performed when an EM is constructed.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.ConnectAsync
member.summary: Connect to the asynchronously.
member.remarks:
Use ConnectAsync and to manage the connection to the EntityServer. You should have an handler in place to catch connection failures.
In Silverlight applications, ConnectAsync is called implicitly when you construct an EntityManager with either the default constructor or a constructor with a true "shouldConnect" argument. In these cases, you may want to check the property before issuing other requests.
Connect does not connect to any backend data sources.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Disconnect
member.summary: Disconnect from the .
member.remarks:
Disconnect marks the connection to the EntityServer as closed. Once disconnected, all further queries will be fulfilled using only cached entities, and any call will fail. Note that a "null" entity is returned for any requested object not found in cache.
Disconnect does not explicitly close data source connections.

member.remarks: You may either "new" a business object (unless it's Abstract (or MustInherit in Visual Basic), or use one of the overloaded CreateEntity methods. Any new entity has a "detached" until added to the EntityManager cache using either or the object's method.

The "entity set" is a construct within the Entity Framework which allows you to logically group entities of the same type. See for more information. If an entity set name is not provided then the is used.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.AddEntity(System.Object)
member.summary: Adds a newly created entity to the EntityManager cache.
member.param: Entity to be added.
member.remarks:
There is no difference between AddEntity and . Use either method to add a business object created by the CreateEntity method to the EntityManager cache. The object must have a "detached" . The added entity will have an entity state of "Added" after this method completes.
If the entity has an auto-incrementing EntityKey, the GenerateId method is called to create a temporary ID. See the Developer Guide for more information on custom ID generation.
The EntityChanging and EntityChanged events fire when this method executes with an EntityAction of .
member.exception: Entity already belongs to another EntityManager

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.AddEntities(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Adds newly created entities to the EntityManager cache.
member.param: Entities to be added.
member.remarks:
Adds business objects created by the method to the EntityManager cache. The objects must have a "detached" . The added entities will have an entity state of "Added" after this method completes.
If an entity has an auto-incrementing , the method is called to create a temporary ID. See the Developers Guide for more information on custom ID generation.
The and events fire when this method executes.
member.exception: Entity already belongs to another EntityManager

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.RemoveEntity(System.Object,System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Removes an from the EntityManager cache.
member.param: The Entity to be removed
Whether removing this entity should also cause the QueryCache to be cleared. The default 'null' value allows DevForce to make this determination based on the entity being removed.
member.remarks:
The will be in a "detached" state after the remove. RemoveEntity and can be used interchangeably
The query cache should normally be cleared after removing an entity from the entity cache, since removing an entity can invalidate the usefulness of the query cache and lead to incorrect query results. You can choose not to clear the query cache if you know that removing the entity will not cause problems.
This does not delete the object from the backend data source. To delete an entity, use the method.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.GetNullEntity(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns a "null" entity of the specified entity type.
member.param: The Entity subtype of the "null" entity to retrieve
member.returns: A "null" entity of the specified Entity subtype
member.remarks:
The null entity is a sentinel object that looks and behaves, for the most part, like a real entity instance. Every entity class defines its own "null entity" instance. When a query method must return an entity and it has no valid entity instance to return, it returns the null entity for the requested entity type instead. When a relation property should return a related entity instance and there is no such instance, it will return a null entity instead.
Only one instance of a null entity exists for any given entity type. You may use to set custom defaults for the null entity. Use to test whether an entity is the null entity.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.InvokeServerMethodAsync(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ServerMethodDelegate,System.Object[])
member.summary: Asynchronously invokes the specified static (Shared in Visual Basic) method for execution on the server.
member.param: Method to be invoked
Arguments to be passed to method
member.remarks:
The method called must be marked with the and correspond to the ServerMethodDelegate signature.
InvokeServerMethodAsync enables a client-side caller to invoke an arbitrary static method on the server using an asynchronous call. The data returned from the server method will be available in the passed to the supplied callback. The server method is called once only. An outstanding request can be canceled using the method.
This feature is only available in certain editions of DevForce.
member.exception: UserState token must be unique for the client
Thrown if the method is not marked with the
Thrown if the server method is decorated with a AuthorizationAttribute and fails authorization

member.summary: Occurs before the EntityManager executes a query.
member.remarks: The event handler can modify the if needed, and set EntityQueryingEventArgs.Cancel to cancel execution of the query. If a query is cancelled, a NullEntity or null entity list will be returned.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Fetching
member.summary: Occurs before the EntityManager fetches data from an EntityServer. This event will only occur if the query will not be satisfied out of the local cache.

member.summary: Occurs after the EntityManager has completed processing of a query.
member.remarks: The list might be empty if the query was satisfied from cache only. If a span query was used, multiple entity types may be found in the list.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Saving
member.summary: Occurs when the EntityManager is preparing to save changes.
member.remarks: The event handler can use the list to validate, modify, delete or add entities as needed. Use EntitySavingEventArgs.Cancel to cancel the save operation. See the DevForce Developer's Guide for more information on the life cycle of a save.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Saved
member.summary: Occurs after the EntityManager has persisted changed entities.
member.remarks: The list contains the entities saved to the data source. See the DevForce Developer's Guide for more information on the life cycle of a save.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.EntityChanging
member.summary: Fired whenever an entity's state is changing in any significant manner.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.EntityChanged
member.summary: Fired whenever an entity's state has changed in any significant manner.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Cleared
member.summary: Fired whenever this entityManager is cleared.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.ConnectionStateChanged
member.summary: Fired when the connection state of the EntityManager changes.
member.remarks:
This event will fire when the EntityManager connects or disconnects from the Entity Server. A connect can occur implicitly, based on arguments to the constructor; or via a call to or . A disconnect can occur via a call to or happen as the result of a communication failure during a request to the EntityServer.
Note that this event will not fire for a lost network connection, as the EntityManager does not monitor network availability. See the class for more information on monitoring network events.

member.name: E:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.EntityServerError
member.summary: Raised when an error occurs while accessing the EntityServer or backend data source.
member.remarks:
The contained within the EntityServerErrorEventArgs will indicate the which was requested when the error occurred, and the of the error. Set to true to indicate that the exception should not be re-thrown.
The EntityServerError event is raised for any type of exception condition which occurs while accessing the EntityServer, including during and Login processing, fetching data, or saving data via SaveChanges.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Options
member.summary: Misc. set of options available to control various aspects of an EntityManager's behavior.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.DefaultQueryStrategy
member.summary: Gets or sets the default QueryStrategy to use for all queries where the QueryStrategy is not set either by parameter or as part of the Query itself.
member.remarks:
You can set the QueryStrategy used by an individual query using its property. The DefaultQueryStrategy is used when a query is executed and the strategy was not provided.
If not set, the default is a QueryStrategy of .

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.DefaultEntityReferenceStrategy
member.summary: Sets the default EntityReferenceStrategy for all references within this EntityManager;

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.DefaultSaveOptions
member.summary: Gets or sets the default options that will be used if no SaveOptions are passed to a SaveChanges method.
member.remarks: If not set, the default is a new instance whose specify that the default transaction settings are used, and is set to All.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.CompositionContext
member.summary: Returns the used by this EntityManager.
member.remarks: You determine the composition context in use when you construct the EntityManager by optionally passing the name of the context wanted. If a name was not provided then the Default composition context is used.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.VerifierEngine
member.summary: Gets or sets the shared by all entities within this EntityManager.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.DataSourceExtension
member.summary: Gets the DataSourceExtension used with this EntityManager.
member.remarks: The DataSourceExtension determines the EntityServer used, as well as the final resolved data source keys.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.EntityServiceOption
member.summary: Gets the EntityServiceOption used to determine whether to connect to a local or distributed Entity Service.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.UsesDistributedEntityService
member.summary: Gets whether this EntityManager uses a distributed Entity Service.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.ServiceKey
member.summary: Gets the name of the serviceKey which defines the EntityServer address.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.AuthenticationContext
member.summary: Gets or sets the used by this EntityManager.
member.remarks:
The AuthenticationContext represents the current authentication state and credentials, of either an individual EntityManager or the application. By default, all EntityManagers use the "default" authentication context, . The setting controls this, and is true by default.
When using the default context, a single login on the Authenticator will set the AuthenticationContext used throughout the application.
An EntityManager can use its own AuthenticationContext if it requires credentials separate from other EntityManagers within the application. Set the to false, and call Login. If you call Authenticator.Login directly, be sure to set the AuthenticationContext to the returned value.
The AuthenticationContext will be null if a Login has not been done.
member.exception: Thrown if try to set the AuthenticationContext to a null value.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets a user-defined value for this EntityManager.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager.AuthorizedThreadId
member.summary: The thread id that this EntityManager is authorized to execute on. An EntityManager can only execute on a single thread at one time.
member.remarks:
This property can be set to another thread id to allow that thread to take over use of the EntityManager. This is an advanced technique and should only be used if you have extensive familiarity with threading.
This property can also be set to null to remove all cross threading checks from the EntityManager. There are a few common cases where this is useful. 1) when executing async tests from within the Visual Studio Test environment (because VS does not use a synchronization context that guarantees that asynchronous calls will be returned to the same thread that created them) or 2) when executing an asynchronous operation from within one of the server side interception methods provided by the EntityServer, or 3) when executing an asynchronous operation from within an ASP.NET worker process.
Unless your case is one of these three or you are very familiar with threading models, we strongly suggest that you do not set this property to null.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IIdGenerator
member.summary: Interface for generation of unique IDs for new objects.
member.remarks:
The IIdGenerator interface defines methods to generate both temporary and real IDs for objects, and to map the temporary IDs to real IDs when objects are persisted to a backend data source. Temporary IDs are created via a call to , and allow entities to be created and uniquely identified while the EntityManager is disconnected from a backend database. Temporary IDs are mapped to real IDs during processing.
Sample code in both VB.NET and C# showing an implementation for ID values of the long datatype is provided with the DevForce installation.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IIdGenerator.GetNextTempId(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.DataEntityProperty)
member.summary: Generates a new temporary ID for a specified EntityProperty.
member.param: Property for which a new ID should be generated
member.returns: A new temporary ID
member.remarks:
The definition of a "temporary" ID is user-defined. In the sample code for a "LongIdGenerator" negative integers are used as temporary IDs.
This method should also store the temporary IDs generated in a .

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IIdGenerator.IsTempId(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.UniqueId)
member.summary: Determines whether a given ID is temporary.
member.param: ID to be analyzed
member.returns: true if the ID is temporary; otherwise false
member.remarks: The contains the ID to be tested. You can use the property of the to determine the type.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IIdGenerator.Reset
member.summary: Reset temporary ID generation back to its initial state.
member.remarks: Called by the after Id fixup during processing.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IIdGenerator.GetRealIdMap(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.UniqueIdCollection,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IDataSourceKey)
member.summary: Returns a dictionary that maps temporary IDs to real IDs.
member.remarks:
In the returned, the key contains the temporary ID, while the value holds the real ID.
GetRealIdMap is called by the during processing. The collection of temporary IDs passed in may contain entries for multiple entity types. You can use the passed to manage access to the backend data source to determine real IDs.
In an n-tier deployment, this method is called only on the "server" instance of this class.
The definition of a "real" ID is user-defined.

member.summary: Arguments to the event.
member.remarks:
The event is fired prior to the execution of any query, regardless of whether the query can be resolved from cache or the data source. This event is fired prior to the event, which fires only when the query must be executed against the data source.
The event handler can set to stop execution of the query, and modify the query prior to execution.

member.summary: Arguments to an event handler.
member.remarks:
If you have subscribed to the event, your handler will receive an instance of EntityQueriedEventArgs for both synchronous and asynchronous query operations.
The Result contains an IEnumerable holding the data fetched. The list might be empty if the query was satisfied from cache only. If a span query was used, multiple entity types may be found in the list.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityScalarAsyncExtensions
member.summary: Provides a set of static methods providing for asynchronous execution of scalar queries.
member.remarks:
To use these extensions, first convert your to an using .
Queries returning a scalar value are called "immediate execution" queries within LINQ. These queries don't actually exist as a query object, but execute immediately to return the desired value. For example, _entityManager.Employees.First() does not return a query, it instead executes immediately, and synchronously, to return the first employee object. When only asynchronous queries are supported, for example in Silverlight applications, converting the query to the IEntityScalarQuery allows you to then use the scalar methods in an asynchronous query.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityServerConnectionException
member.summary: Exception thrown for connection-related failures.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityServerException
member.summary: Exception thrown by the EntityServer for persistence failures.
member.remarks:
A EntityServerException, or one of its sub-types, can be thrown for a number of error conditions detected while the communicates with the . It can be raised during and Login processing, while fetching data, or saving data via SaveChanges.
The EntityServerException is first raised via the event. If a handler is in place for this event you can choose to handle the error and set the property value to true. If a handler is not found or the Handled property is not set, the EntityServerException is thrown back to the calling code.
The of the exception indicates the general type of failure condition. The indicates the type of persistence operation requested when the error occurred. The will have additional information on the error.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.Authenticator
member.summary: Provides authentication services in a DevForce application.
member.remarks: Call synchronous and asynchronous Login and Logout methods on the singleton to validate user credentials in your application.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.Authenticator.Instance
member.summary: The singleton instance of the Authenticator.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.Authenticator.LoginAsync(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ILoginCredential,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.LoginOptions)
member.summary: Perform an asynchronous login operation to validate user credentials against an Entity Server.
member.remarks:
The can be used to specify the EntityServer. If options are not provided, the "default" EntityServer is assumed.
You can pass a null (Nothing in Visual Basic) in place of an object. Null credentials can indicate either that the user is logging in as a guest or anonymous user, or when using the AspAuthenticatingLoginManager that the current authenticated user should be loaded. When using ASP.NET the current authenticated user is one authenticated via Windows authentication, or is the user already logged in because of either a persistent cookie or a login performed elsewhere in the ASP.NET application. If you are not using the AspAuthenticationLoginManager then your implementation of should handle a null credential if your client application can provide one.
The AllowAnonymousLogin flag in the IdeaBlade configuration determines whether "anonymous" users can login to your application. Anonymous users are ones who have not supplied credentials and who also cannot be authenticated by other means, such as ASP.NET authentication.
Provide a if you want to be notified when the operation completes. Use the to uniquely identify this call.
The returned from a successful login in the or can be used in two ways: 1) you can set the so that any in your application will share the credentials and not require a separate login, or 2) you can set the on one or more EntityManager instances. Note that without performing one of these actions the returned AuthenticationContext will not be used by DevForce.
Credentials are passed in clear text. Use a secure channel (such as SSL) or provide your own encryption if secure communications are necessary.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.Authenticator.LogoutAsync(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.IAuthenticationContext)
member.summary: Perform an asynchronous operation to log the specified out of the Entity Server.
member.remarks: Any using this AuthenticationContext will be logged out.

member.name: P:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.Authenticator.DefaultAuthenticationContext
member.summary: The "default" .
member.remarks: You may directly set the DefaultAuthenticationContext using the returned from a Login or LoginAsync call. Any with a setting of true will then not need to be logged in separately, and will use the shared context set here. Using the DefaultAuthenticationContext provides single sign-on and single sign-off capabilities to your application.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Security.LoginOptions
member.summary: Determine the characteristics of the EntityServer to authenticate against.
member.remarks:
Validation of user credentials can be performed either for a specific or for the application as a whole. An will communicate with a specific EntityServer, one having the same data source extension and composition context name. By default, the synchronous and asynchronous Login calls made from an EntityManager will use LoginOptions reflecting the EntityServer in use.
When calling the Authenticator.Login directly, you may choose which EntityServer to authenticate against by specifying the LoginOptions.

member.summary: Saves an object to a Stream, optionally closing the stream when done.
member.remarks:
The object is serialized to the stream in either binary or text format.
If the flag is on, the object is serialized with the DataContractSerializer; otherwise the NetDataContractSerializer is used. UseDCS is on by default, and is assumed to be on in Silverlight, where the NDCS serializer is not supported.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.SerializationContext.ThreadLocalMode
member.summary: This property is used to control the mechanism that DevForce uses to serialize entity graphs. This is a static 'ThreadLocal' property meaning that it may be set independently on each thread but is 'global' to that thread. If this property is set to SerializationContextMode.Default the the SerializationContext.DefaultMode value is to control serialization instead. See .
member.remarks: This property will normally not need to be set. It should only be needed if stack overflow exceptions are occuring during entity graph serialization operations. If this occurs this property can be set to SerializationContextMode.Alternate.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityListManager`1
member.summary: Manages any list of Entities to ensure the list stays current with specified filtering criteria.
member.remarks:
An EntityListManager can turn any concrete implementation into a "live" or managed list. By specifying a and the EntityListManager will ensure that any changes, additions or deletions to entities meeting the filtering criteria are automatically reflected in the list.
Use and to add or remove lists under management. All lists managed by an EntityListManager must contain the same Entity type.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityListManager`1.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,System.Predicate{`0},IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityProperty[])
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityListManager.
member.param: EntityManager holding the Entities
A predicate returning true if the tested entity belongs in the list
The watched properties. If supplied, changes to values in the watched properties trigger filtering. If null, any changes to Entities of this type will trigger filtering.
member.remarks:
The uses a .NET Predicate<T>, a delegate that defines a set of criteria and determines whether the specified object passed to it meets those criteria. The Filter receives every addition, deletion or modification (based on the specified) of entities of the type watched, and determines whether the entity belongs in the list. If the Filter returns true the entity is added to or kept in the list; if the Filter returns false the entity is removed from the list. (Note that entities removed from the managed list are not removed from the EntityManager, nor are they deleted.)
Performance will be needlessly poor if the EntityListManager tests an entity every time any of its properties change. To avoid this, specify in the constructor or the property which entity properties are relevant to the filtering.
An EntityListManager holds weak references to the Lists it watches. This means that you will need to hold on to a reference to each ELM to insure that it does not go out of scope and get garbage collected. One approach to this is to use Lists that implement the interface. This will insure each list keeps a reference to its ELM and any shared ELM's will not go out of scope until the last of their child lists do.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityListManager`1.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,System.Predicate{`0},IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityProperty[],System.Collections.IList,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityListManager.
member.param: EntityManager holding the Entities
A predicate returning true if the tested entity belongs in the list
The watched properties. If supplied, changes to values in the watched properties trigger filtering. If null, any changes to Entities of this type will trigger filtering.
The list to be managed
If true, immediately refresh the list for the filtering criteria
member.remarks:
The uses a .NET Predicate<T>, a delegate that defines a set of criteria and determines whether the specified object passed to it meets those criteria. The Filter receives every addition, deletion or modification (based on the specified) of entities of the type watched, and determines whether the entity belongs in the list. If the Filter returns true the entity is added to or kept in the list; if the Filter returns false the entity is removed from the list. (Note that entities removed from the managed list are not removed from the EntityManager, nor are they deleted.)
Performance will be needlessly poor if the EntityListManager tests an entity every time any of its properties change. To avoid this, specify in the constructor or the property which entity properties are relevant to the filtering.
You can choose to have the EntityListManager refresh the list immediately after assuming management of the list. This is unnecessary if the supplied list is known to be complete at the time the manager is initialized.
An EntityListManager holds weak references to the Lists it watches. This means that you will need to hold on to a reference to each ELM to insure that it does not go out of scope and get garbage collected. One approach to this is to use Lists that implement the interface. This will insure each list keeps a reference to its ELM and any shared ELM's will not go out of scope until the last of their child lists do.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.Entity
member.summary: Abstract (MustInherit in Visual Basic) base class for all persistable business objects used within DevForce.
member.remarks:
Instances of Entity are not created directly; instead, every persistable business object type inherits from Entity.
Entity objects are managed and cached by a . You'll use an EntityManager to create, retrieve and save your entities. The EntityManager will also handle serialization and transfer of entities to a distributed Object Server.
When working with business objects, you will generally focus on creating additional properties to support business logic and rules; basic properties are auto-generated for you by the IdeaBlade DevForce Object Mapping Tool when business objects are designed.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryFilterCollection
member.summary: An independent collection of query filters.
member.remarks:
Use the EntityQueryFilterCollection to create a collection of filters for different entity types. You can create the collection independent of your queries and apply the filters when needed, for example in a server-side EntityServerQueryInterceptor implementation using the Filter extension method.
The collection may contain only one query filter per entity type, but may contain any number of filters. When applied to an , only the applicable filters will be used. For example, if you'ved added filters for both the Customer and Employee entity types to a collection and apply this to a query of Customers, only the pertinent filter will be applied.

member.remarks: See for information on adding filters to the collection.

member.param: A Func that takes and returns an IQueryable{T}
member.remarks: The , although it looks intimidating, is really a simple Where predicate which you're already familiar with when using query expression syntax. See the example for more information.
member.exception: Thrown if a filter for the entity type is already in the collection and the canReplaceIfAlreadyExists paremter is set to false

member.summary: Representation of a relational property within an .
member.remarks: The IdeaBlade DevForce Object Mapping Tool automatically generates EntityProperties for your business objects: a DataEntityProperty is generated for all simple properties, and a is generated for all relational properties.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityProperty
member.summary: Representation of a single property within an .
member.remarks:
The IdeaBlade DevForce Object Mapping Tool automatically generates EntityProperties for your business objects: a is generated for all simple properties, and a is generated for all relational properties.
The auto-generated EntityProperties are statically defined within each Entity class and are constructed when the Entity types are loaded, which usually occurs when the assembly is loaded and the EntityRelations.Initialize method is called by DevForce.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.UserBase
member.summary: The default implementation within DevForce.
member.remarks:
Represents the current user in DevForce application. When a custom is used you may return either a UserBase or any standard or custom implementation.
When a UserBase is returned by a Login call, it will be available in the client application through the Principal property on the . For methods invoked on the server, the Thread.CurrentPrincipal will return a UserBase instance, as will the method's IPrincipal argument if specified.
If you are using ASP.NET security and have enabled the ASP.NET Role Manager you can use UserBase to perform role-based authorization within your application using either declarative or imperative security checks.
If you use the ASP.NET Profile feature the profile properties will automatically be set in your custom UserBase implementation. Any properties in your custom class which match the Profile properties in name and data type will be set by the AspAuthenticatingLoginManager. Be sure that your custom class extends UserBase.
You can also extend UserBase and AspAuthenticatingLoginManager to add additional application-specific properties and logic. Make sure that you decorate your custom UserBase type with a DataContract attribute.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.UserBase.#ctor(System.Security.Principal.IIdentity,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Creates an instance of this class.
member.remarks:
A UserBase is returned by DevForce when you are using the AspAuthenticatingLoginManager, and if you allow anonymous logins but have not implemented a custom .
If you have extended the UserBase base type, you must include a public constructor with the signature below.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IKnownType
member.summary: Marker interface for specification of known types.
member.remarks:
A "known type" is a type which the DataContractSerializer knows how to serialize. DevForce uses this serializer in Silverlight applications, or in any n-tier application in which the Object Server UseDCS flag has been set. DevForce will automatically discover most known types, but in some situations you will also need to specify the known types for DevForce to use. You can do this in several ways: 1) use this marker interface, 2) decorate the type with the , 3) decorate an existing known type with the , or 4) implement the to programmatically add known types.
The types which you need to make known to DevForce are typically those used with the EntityManager.InvokeServerMethod or the Notification Service.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.IKnownTypeProvider
member.summary: Interface which allows for programmatic specification of known types.
member.remarks:
A "known type" is a type which the DataContractSerializer knows how to serialize. DevForce uses this serializer in Silverlight applications, or in any n-tier application in which the Object Server UseDCS flag has been set. DevForce will automatically discover most known types, but in some situations you will also need to specify the known types for DevForce to use. You can do this in several ways: 1) use the marker interface , 2) decorate the type with the , 3) decorate an existing known type with the , or 4) implement the IKnownTypeProvider to programmatically add known types.
The types which you need to make known to DevForce are typically those used with the EntityManager.InvokeServerMethod or the Notification Service.
DevForce will find and use all implementations of the IKnownTypeProvider interface.

member.summary: Provide any types for the DataContractSerializer which DevForce won't otherwise discover.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityFetchingEventArgs
member.summary: Arguments to the event.
member.remarks: The event is fired before the EntityManager fetches data from an EntityServer. Note that cache only queries or optimized queries that are handled from cache will not go through this handler. The provided in this event may be "reduced" from the query initially submitted to satisfy internal processing requirements. If you need to see or modify the original query you should provide a handler for the event. Set to cancel the fetch.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy
member.summary: Strategy to control how Entities are merged into an EntityManager's cache.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy.NotApplicable
member.summary: No merge action applies because there is no data source data. This merge strategy must be used and may only be used with the CacheOnly fetch strategy.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy.OverwriteChanges
member.summary: Overwrites the cached entity with incoming data and uses the EntityState of the incoming entity (will be Unchanged if the incoming entity is from the data source).

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy.PreserveChanges
member.summary: Preserves (does not overwrite) any existing entities that have been changed (modified, added or deleted).

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy.PreserveChangesUnlessOriginalObsolete
member.summary: Preserves the persistent state of the cached entity if the entity is current. Overwrites an entity if it is obsolete and gives it the EntityState of the incoming entity (will be Unchanged if the incoming entity is from the data source).

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.MergeStrategy.PreserveChangesUpdateOriginal
member.summary: Preserves the persistent state of the cached entity whether it is current or not. Overwrites the Original version of the entity if obsolete.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy
member.summary: Determines the , , and to use when retrieving entities.
member.remarks: All pre-defined static QueryStrategy objects use a which defaults to not use DTC. If you need to perform transactional fetches you will need to set the appropriate TransactionSettings values.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy.DataSourceOnly
member.summary: Retrieve entities from the back-end data source only, and overwrite any matching entities. QueryInversion is turned off for this strategy.
member.remarks: Combines and .

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy.DataSourceOnlyWithInversion
member.summary: Retrieve entities from the back-end data source only, and overwrite any matching entities. QueryInversion is turned on for this strategy.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy.DataSourceThenCache
member.summary: Retrieve entities from the backend data source, add objects from cache, and overwrite any matching entities. QueryInversion is set to 'Try' for this strategy.
member.remarks: Combines and .

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy.Normal
member.summary: Retrieve business objects from the cache, and if not in cache, the back-end data source, preserving any changes. QueryInversion is set to 'Try' for this strategy.
member.remarks: Combines and .

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.QueryStrategy.CacheOnly
member.summary: Retrieve business objects from the cache only. QueryInversion is not applicable for this strategy.
member.remarks: Combines and .

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ClientEdmKey
member.summary: Represents the connection information to a database.
member.remarks:
By default an EdmKey is created from the connection information for a matching element in the ConnectionStrings section of your configuration file. You can override this default by specifying an EdmKey in the IdeaBlade section of the configuration file. You can also create an EdmKey at run-time by implementing a custom .
The ClientEdmKey is a client-side version of the EdmKey and requires no connection string information. If you implement a custom the method will be called with a client-side key when invoked on the client, and with the server-side EdmKey when invoked on the server.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy
member.summary: The strategy to use when working with a 'concurrency' .
member.remarks:
The DevForce Object Mapping tool allows you to set a ConcurrencyStrategy for every property to be used as a concurrency field. Concurrency properties are used to support optimistic concurrency checking during processing.
If you choose a strategy of then you must implement a custom so that your callback routine will be called during save processing.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.None
member.summary: The property is not a concurrency field.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.AutoGuid
member.summary: Allow DevForce to automatically assign a new Guid to the property upon insert or update.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.AutoDateTime
member.summary: Allow DevForce to automatically set the current date and time to the property upon insert or update.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.AutoIncrement
member.summary: Allow DevForce to automatically increment a numeric field by 1 upon insert or update.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.ServerCallback
member.summary: Call a custom upon insert or update.

member.name: F:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ConcurrencyStrategy.Client
member.summary: The property is a concurrency field, but the client application is responsible for maintaining the value.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityRelation
member.summary: Represents a relationship between two subtypes.
member.remarks:
EntityRelation objects are automatically generated for you by the IdeaBlade DevForce Object Mapping Tool for any relationships defined during design, and placed in a class called EntityRelations in your doman model.
The EntityRelation corresponds to an association in the conceptual model of your Entity Domain Model. There are two ends to every relation: and . The multiplicity of the two ends determines the multiplicity of the relation.

member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityRelation class.
member.param: The entity type for role1
The entity type for role2
An array of role1 s
A corresponding array of role2 s
Multiplicity of the role1 end
Multiplicity of the role2 end
Action to take upon delete of a role1 entity
Action to take upon delete of a role2 entity
The non-namespace qualified name representing the role1/role2 relation.
member.remarks:
EntityRelations are automatically generated by the DevForce Object Mapping tool, and you will not usually need to construct additional instances. You can retrieve one or more EntityRelations using one of the overloads.
Note that the role1Type and role2Type cannot necessarily be inferred from role1Properties and role2Properties because of type inheritence. For example, the role1Type may be a subclass of the role1Properties[0].EntityType.
The relation name provided here should not be namespace-qualified. Namespace qualifiers are added automatically at run time to ensure that relation names are unique across all models loaded.
member.exception: Relation names must be universally unique.

Note that the role1Type and role2Type cannot necessarily be inferred from role1Properties and role2Properties because of type inheritence. For example, the role1Type may be a subclass of the role1Properties[0].EntityType.
The relation name provided here should not be namespace-qualified. Namespace qualifiers are added automatically at run time to ensure that relation names are unique across all models loaded.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityReferenceBase
member.summary: Abstract base class that all implementations of extend. Internal use only. There will be one entityReference per navigation property per entity. An EntityReference contains both the metadata about a specific navigation properties relation as well as the resolution status of the navigation property. It can be viewed as the backing store for any navigation property ( with additional status and metadata info).

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.ParameterizedEsql
member.summary: Represents an Entity SQL statement with parameters.
member.remarks:
A ParameterizedEsql holds an Entity SQL (eSQL) statement with parameter placeholders and an associated collection. This collection cannot be modified after creating the ParameterizedEsql object, but the values of the parameters in the collection can be changed.
A ParameterizedEsql object is used when creating a .

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.PassthruEsqlQuery
member.summary: Used to execute an Entity SQL statement within the DevForce framework.
member.remarks:
A PassthruEsqlQuery can be used to retrieve objects from an . You might want to build an Entity SQL (eSQL) query instead of a standard for performance reasons or for complex eSQL statements. Queries are submitted using or one of the available overloads.
A PassthruEsqlQuery must always use a of DataSourceOnly, and cannot be used when disconnected from the EntityServer.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryExtensions.Filter``1(``0,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryFilterCollection)
member.summary: Append the specified filter collection to the query.
member.param: Query to be appended to
Collection of filters
member.returns: A new query
member.remarks:
You can use an to filter different entity types in the query. The collection can also contain filters for types not currently in the query, and those filters will be ignored when the query is executed.
The Filter is most useful in appending to an existing query on the server prior to execution, where you cannot easily modify the query expression provided. The query may also be filtered on the client using the event.
Note that Filter returns a new query with the filter(s) added; the original query is not modified.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryExtensions.Filter``2(``0,System.Func{System.Linq.IQueryable{``1},System.Linq.IQueryable{``1}})
member.summary: Append a filter to the query.
member.typeparam: Entity type of the new query returned
member.param: Query to be appended to
A Func that takes and returns an IQueryable{T}
member.returns: A new query
member.remarks:
A Filter is most useful in appending to an existing query on the server prior to execution, where you cannot easily modify the query expression provided.
The , although it looks intimidating, is a simple Where predicate which you're already familiar with when using query expression syntax. See the example for more information.
This signature is used when the entity type of the filter is different than that of the query.
Note that Filter returns a new query with the filter(s) added; the original query is not modified.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQueryExtensions.Include``1(``0,System.String)
member.summary: Configures eager fetching for related entities in the specified query path.
member.param: An EntityQuery
Dot-separated list of navigation properties that describe the query path in the graph that should be eagerly fetched.
member.returns: A new with the defined query path.
member.remarks:
The may represent a simple or complex navigation. For example, if a Customer type has an Orders navigation property, and the Order type has OrderDetails, you can use a property path of "Orders" to eagerly load orders for any customer queried, and you can use "Orders.OrderDetails" to eagerly load both orders and details for queried customers. Note that the complex property path might not be a valid navigation if a collection is returned, as with "Orders.OrderDetails", but instances of the collection must have the indicated property (e.g., anOrder.OrderDetails). All "parts" in the property path will be pre-loaded into the EntityManager cache when the query is executed.
Multiple "Includes" may be added to a query.

member.summary: Configures eager fetching for related entities in the specified query path.
member.param: An EntityQuery

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityQuery`1
member.summary: Represents a Language-Integrated Query (LINQ) against either the backend data source or the cache.
member.remarks:
The DevForce Object Mapping tool auto-generates an appropriately typed EntityQuery<T> property on your sub-typed EntityManager for every entity set defined in your domain model. You can execute these queries as is, or add additional clauses using either "method" or "query" LINQ syntax. You can also construct new queries.
An EntityQuery<T> can be executed in several ways. First, you can use LINQ deferred execution: that is the query is automatically executed as you begin iterating over the query variable using a foreach statement. The query's and determine how the query results are obtained.
You can force immediate execution of the EntityQuery<T> by calling either ToList() or ToArray() on the query. This again will use the query's and to determine how the query results are obtained.
You can also use one of the many ExecuteQuery methods defined on the . These methods give you additonal control over how the query is executed, but are functionally equivalent to using either the standard deferred and immediate methods of LINQ.
DevForce supports all the LINQ standard query operators supported by the Microsoft Entity Framework (EF), as well as some operators not yet supported in EF. Check the DevForce Developer's Guide for more information.
An EntityQuery<T> can be used in either 2-tier or n-tier DevForce deployments without modification. In n-tier implementations DevForce will serialize the query to the BOS for execution and return appropriate results to the client. Note that queries returning anonymous types can also be used in either 2-tier or n-tier.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.DataSourceKeyNameAttribute
member.summary: Defines an attribute that associates an Entity subclass with a DataSourceKeyName.
member.remarks: This attribute is auto-generated by the Object Mapper on each Entity class using the name of the data source key specified for the Entity Model. It is also generated on each EntityManager partial class to indicate which datasource keys are present within the EntityManager. Multiple datasource key attributes may be marked on a single EntityManager because an EntityManager may consist of multiple partial classes each representing a different data source. At run time, the actual data source key used is resolved based on the DataSourceKeyName attribute and the data source extension used by the Entity Manager.

member.summary: The key name.

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityCacheState
member.summary: A serializable collection of Entities that can be retrieved from an EntityManager.
member.remarks:
An EntityCacheState is retrieved from an via the method; it can then be serialized and stored. The EntityCacheState can be restored by deserializing the contents and calling either the or methods.
The and methods of the class provide additional serialization and deserialization capabilities. You can use EntityCacheState directly if you prefer additional control over this processing. You will normally work with the EntityCacheState via the EntityManager's property.

example.code:
Private Sub SampleEntityCacheUsage()
Dim mgr As New DomainModelEntityManager()
' Cache all employees. mgr.ExecuteQuery(Of Employee)()
' Save the cache to local storage. mgr.CacheStateManager.SaveCacheState("c:\temp\entitycache.bin")
' Ocassionally-connected users will normally connect, cache all data required, ' then disconnect and work from local cache and/or locally saved cache until they can reconnect. ' In this example, we'll mimic a disconnected login for this user by clearing all cached data ' and then re-loading the cache from local storage. mgr.Disconnect() mgr.Clear()
mgr.CacheStateManager.RestoreCacheState("c:\temp\entitycache.bin")
' Let's reconnect and get more data now. mgr.Connect() mgr.ExecuteQuery(Of Customer)() End Sub

members.member:
Initialize a new instance of the EntityCacheState class.
Use this constructor to create an EntityCacheState for all items in the cache.
This ctor should only be called internally because if keeps an internal ref to the entityManager and therefor needs to be used immediately before the entityManager changes or should be cloned ( see DeepClone).

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityCacheState.#ctor(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of the EntityCacheState class using the list of entities specified.
member.param: List of Entities
member.remarks:
Use this constructor to create an EntityCacheState for only the items passed in the parameter.
If any temporary Ids have been assigned to entities in the list provided, all related entities which reference the temporary Id must also be included. For example, if an Order has been assigned a temporary Id of -1, the Order and all its OrderDetails must be included in the list, not only the Order or only the OrderDetails.
member.exception: Thrown if temporary Id references cannot be resolved

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityCacheState.Save(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves the EntityCacheState to a Stream, optionally closing the stream when done.
member.param: True to close the stream when done; false to leave the stream open for additional processing.
True to save the file in binary format, false to save in text format.
member.remarks: The EntityCacheState can be serialized to the stream in either binary or text format.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityCacheState.Restore(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Static (Shared in Visual Basic) method which creates and loads an EntityCacheState from the stream specified.
member.param: Stream to be read
Whether or not to close the stream when done.
True to restore a file in binary format, false to restore a file in text format.
member.returns: An EntityCacheState
member.remarks:
Use Restore to deserialize an EntityCacheState which was previously saved to a stream or file.
Note that this method does not merge the EntityCacheState into an . Call or for this. Instead of performing the Restore and merge/restore as separate steps, you can instead use to accomplish the same thing.

member.name: M:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityCacheState.Merge(IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityManager,IdeaBlade.EntityModel.RestoreStrategy)
member.summary: Merges this EntityCacheState into an EntityManager.
member.param: EntityManager to merge data into
The restore strategy to use
member.returns: An collection of original entityKeys and the EntityAspects that they were merged into
member.remarks:
Merge is functionally equivalent to the
method in .

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntitySpan
member.summary: A chained collection of s used by .
member.remarks:
A single EntitySpan represents the relations among a graph of entities. You must be able to "walk" the spans without jumping or backtracking. For example, a single EntitySpan might be defined for Customer -> Order -> OrderDetails, because relationships are defined between each of these entities and navigation is straightforward. You cannot, however define a single span for Customer -> Order -> OrderDetails -> Employee, because navigation from OrderDetails to Employee is not defined. In this case two spans would be required, one for Customer -> Order -> OrderDetails, and another for Customer -> Order -> Employee.
The EntitySpan is used in retrieving an entity graph with

member.param: Root Entity type

member.remarks:
A single EntitySpan represents the relations among a graph of entities. You must be able to "walk" the spans without jumping or backtracking.
The EntitySpan is used in retrieving an entity graph with
member.exception: Thrown if the relationships are ambiguous or do not connect

member.name: T:IdeaBlade.EntityModel.EntityGroup
member.summary: Abstract base class for the class.
member.remarks:
An EntityGroup is used within the framework to hold entities of a specific type. With the exception of some events provided by the EntityGroup, you will rarely need to work with this class directly.
The EntityGroup provides several pre- and post- change events at both the property and entity levels. You can subscribe to and to handle property-level changes to your entities. You can subscribe to and to listen for any change to your entities.
You can obtain an EntityGroup instance from an using .
